comment.author: 23103743@N05
comment._content: Acording to www.akpool.co.uk/postcards/24155901-postcard-gotha-eisene... this statue was erected Sept 26, 1915. According to en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Etrich_Taube The Taube was a "pre-World War I monoplane aircraft. It was the first mass-produced military plane in Germany." www.pictorialgems.com/1916-Gotha-Taube-Memorial-To-German... shows this picture printed in the Illustrated War News of February 16, 1916

comment.author: 76016463@N00
comment._content: This plane with the birdlike tail (the name translates to English as "dove") was reportedly responsible for bombings in Paris in October, 1914. query.nytimes.com/mem/archive-free/pdf?res=9A07E4DA1438E0... A Bain photo of the damage:

comment.author: 38714066@N00
comment._content: It looks like the sort of memorial you could pay to drive a nail into.  See the leading edge of the wing, and the engine.

comment.author: 66311327@N05
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/sethgaines] That's correct, the memorial is on a list of "Kriegsnagelungen" (war nailings) (with the same postcard as in swanq's comment), see www.munzel-everling.de/download/Kriegsnagelungen_August_2.... Another example of such a memorial was the "Eiserne Hindenburg" in Berlin Tiergarten see comments there

comment.author: 76016463@N00
comment._content: ""Kriegsnagelungen".  I never knew of these, thanks.  I wonder if this monument still exists?  I can't find any trace of it.

comment.author: 66311327@N05
comment._content: I'm quite sure that none of these monuments exists anymore at its original place, some are perhaps in a museum now. Despite of the label "eisern" (iron), these monuments were made of wood. The "Eiserne Hindenburg" e.g. was used as firewood after the war (except the head, which burned in WWII, see de.wikipedia.org/wiki/Eiserner_Hindenburg, in German).

comment.author: 23103743@N05
comment._content: en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Nail_Men is another source of information. Intriguing!

comment.author: 38714066@N00
comment._content: Yes, I suppose the idea was that it would become 'iron' from all the patriotic folks putting nails into it.  They are fascinating.  I'm glad to see so many have survived.
